‘Avdotya Romanovna,’ Luzhin said, clearly annoyed, ‘your words matter way too much to me. Honestly, they’re offensive given my position with you. Not to mention, you’re comparing me to some rude kid. You’re even suggesting you might break your promise to me. When you say ‘you or he,’ it shows how little I mean to you… I can’t just let this slide, considering our relationship and the obligations we have.’

‘What!’ Dounia exclaimed, her face flushing. ‘I’m putting your interests next to everything that’s been most important in my life, the stuff that makes up who I am, and you’re upset because I don’t value you enough?’

Raskolnikov smirked sarcastically, Razumihin fidgeted, but Luzhin didn’t take the hint. Instead, he got even more pushy and irritable, almost enjoying the tension. 

‘Your love for the future partner in your life, your husband, should be stronger than your love for your brother,’ he declared dramatically. ‘And I can’t be compared to him… Even though I promised not to speak openly in your brother’s presence, I need to ask your mother for an important clarification that affects my dignity. Your son,’ he turned to Pulcheria Alexandrovna, ‘yesterday in front of Mr. Razumihin (or… I think that’s right? Sorry, I forgot your name)…’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Luzhin expresses his irritation and offense at Dounia's perceived disrespect towards him and his position in their relationship.
